### ‚ñ∂Ô∏è First Run
- ‚úÖ **Run the first group first**
- üîá **Mute the second group**

### üìã After the First Run
- üìé **Copy & paste the output** into the corresponding input fields of the other groups
- üßπ If a JSON output has extra characters (for example:  
  ````json  
  at the start), **delete them** or the workflow will ‚ùå fail

### üìÇ Prompt Batcher Setup
- üìÅ In the **Prompt Batcher** node, choose an **empty folder path**
- üíæ This is where the prompts will be saved so they can be **combined later**

### üîÅ Second Run
- üîá **Mute the first group**
- ‚ñ∂Ô∏è **Run the workflow again**

### ‚öôÔ∏è What Happens Next
- ‚è≥ The batches will **auto-queue**
- ‚úÖ Once finished, it will output a **full JSON prompt list**
- üîÑ Use this final JSON in the **other workflow**

CINEMATIC TEXT-TO-VIDEO PROMPT INSTRUCTIONS ‚Äî TWO-SCENE CONTINUOUS MORPH VERSION
PURPOSE

Generate cinematic visual prompts for a text-to-video system.
Purely visual.
No sound.
No dialogue.
No on-screen text.
No metaphors.
No symbolic language.

Each output is a valid JSON code block containing "prompt1", "prompt2", etc.
All prompts are generated at once.
No questions.

INPUT REQUIREMENTS
A) Lyric Segments (User-Provided JSON)

The user provides song lyrics in sequential order, separated into equal timing segments:

{
  "Lyricsegment1": "...",
  "Lyricsegment2": "...",
  "Lyricsegment3": "..."
}
‚Ä¢ Lyrics represent emotional and narrative progression.
‚Ä¢ Lyrics never appear visually or as audio.
‚Ä¢ Interpret meaning into pure, physical visuals.
If a lyric contains a concrete physical noun or action, its visible counterpart must appear explicitly in the i2v scene text, or the output is invalid.

B) Story Concept

Defines the visual world, tone, characters, and transformation arc.
Guides the continuity across all prompts.

CRITICAL INTERPRETATION RULES

Lyrics are not dialogue.
Lyrics must never be spoken, written, or displayed.

No metaphors.
No symbolic language.
No describing emotions.

Only literal, observable, cinematic physical reality.

Visual narrative must be based strictly on:
‚Ä¢ Environment
‚Ä¢ Physical transformation
‚Ä¢ Character or subject changes

TWO-SCENE CONTINUOUS MORPH STRUCTURE

Each prompt contains two morphing scenes forming one uninterrupted shot.

Each scene must be 80‚Äì100 words.
Total length per prompt: 160‚Äì200 words.

Structure per prompt:

Position	Content	Morph Requirement
Scene 1	New visual state derived from lyric segment	Begins by continuing the morph that ended previous prompt
Scene 1 end		Starts a specific physical morph event
Scene 2 start		Continues that exact morph event
Scene 2 end	Final form of this narrative moment	Starts a new morph event that will begin next prompt

No hard cuts.
Morphing replaces the camera.

Forbidden continuity language:
‚Ä¢ still
‚Ä¢ continues
‚Ä¢ after
‚Ä¢ before
‚Ä¢ next
‚Ä¢ again

MIRRORED MORPH TRANSITION RULE

Every Scene 2 ending must include a clear physical transformation mid-motion.

The next prompt‚Äôs Scene 1 must begin by continuing the exact same morph using identical physical action language.

This lock must be explicit and unbroken.

CONTINUOUS INHERITANCE RULE

Prompt 1 begins fresh.

All later prompts:

‚Ä¢ Scene 1 is an exact duplicate of the previous prompt‚Äôs Scene 2
‚Ä¢ Text must be pasted verbatim with no change in wording or formatting
‚Ä¢ Scene 2 is newly generated

No reference language such as:
‚Ä¢ same as before
‚Ä¢ earlier scene

Repeated text must read as fresh observation.

SELF-CONTAINED DESCRIPTION REQUIREMENTS

Each prompt must be complete and cinematic on its own.

Do not reference:
‚Ä¢ camera movement
‚Ä¢ emotional state
‚Ä¢ memory or timeline markers

Describe only what is physically visible.

TEXT-TO-IMAGE PROMPT GENERATION (Z-IMAGE FORMAT)

Each prompt must include a Text-to-Image prompt field named "t2i".

Text-to-Image prompts must be written as clear, explicit, camera-style positive descriptions suitable for Z-Image image generation.

Each "t2i" prompt must be a single natural-language paragraph.

REQUIRED CONTENT (MANDATORY)

Each Text-to-Image prompt must explicitly describe:

‚Ä¢ Shot type and framing
‚Ä¢ Subject physical appearance
‚Ä¢ Clothing, material, or surface detail
‚Ä¢ Anatomical or structural detail
‚Ä¢ Environment and background
‚Ä¢ Lighting conditions
‚Ä¢ Visual tone (aesthetic only)
‚Ä¢ Render style and realism anchor

Descriptions must be literal, physical, and concrete.

LANGUAGE AND DESCRIPTION RULES (CRITICAL)

Text-to-Image prompts must describe only what is directly and physically visible in a single static frame.

The following are strictly forbidden:

‚Ä¢ Sound or audio references of any kind
‚Ä¢ Metaphors or similes (no ‚Äúlike‚Äù, ‚Äúas if‚Äù, ‚Äúresembles‚Äù)
‚Ä¢ Anthropomorphic language (no breathing, exhaling, reacting, feeling, awakening)
‚Ä¢ Implied emotion, intention, or awareness
‚Ä¢ Abstract or symbolic phrasing
‚Ä¢ Comparisons to living processes

Descriptions must not interpret or suggest meaning.
They must only state observable physical facts.

STYLE AND LANGUAGE GUIDELINES

‚Ä¢ Write as if documenting a real physical scene for a camera crew
‚Ä¢ Use direct, technical, observational language
‚Ä¢ Prefer explicit nouns and verbs over descriptive flourish
‚Ä¢ Avoid poetic or novel-like phrasing

The prompt should read like a precise visual specification, not a narrative.

GROUPING RULES 
Prompts are organized into sequential groups of sixteen.

The first prompt of each group (1, 17, 33, 49, ‚Ä¶) must contain two Text-to-Image prompts.
All other prompts must contain one Text-to-Image prompt.

‚Ä¢ When two Text-to-Image prompts are required:
‚Äì The first is derived from Scene 1
‚Äì The second is derived from Scene 2

‚Ä¢ When one Text-to-Image prompt is required:
‚Äì It is derived from Scene 2 only

When two prompts are required, they must be returned as one string, separated by a newline.

INDEX TRIGGER RULE (HARD CONSTRAINT)
For promptN, determine group-start using this exact condition:
GroupStart = (N = 1) OR ((N ‚àí 1) mod 16 = 0)
If GroupStart is true, "t2i" MUST contain two newline-separated paragraphs: first from Scene 1, second from Scene 2.
If GroupStart is false, "t2i" MUST contain exactly one paragraph derived from Scene 2.


TEXT-TO-IMAGE PROMPT INTENT

Each Text-to-Image prompt represents a single, fully resolved static visual frame.

They must not include:

‚Ä¢ Motion or morphing language
‚Ä¢ Temporal progression
‚Ä¢ Sound
‚Ä¢ Dialogue
‚Ä¢ On-screen text

The described image must represent a stable, physically complete visual state.

T2I ISOLATION OVERRIDE ‚Äî NON-NEGOTIABLE

The Text-to-Image (t2i) field must be generated under TOTAL CONTEXT AMNESIA.

The model MUST assume:

The image generator has zero memory

No previous frames exist

No prior prompts exist

No continuity exists

Every t2i prompt must describe a single static frame as if it is the first and only image ever generated.

‚ùå ABSOLUTELY FORBIDDEN IN T2I

The following are hard errors and must never appear in t2i:

Continuity / Memory Words

same, remains, still, now, again, continues, previously, earlier, later


Persistence Verbs

remains, stays, keeps, continues, holds


Relational Language

another, identical, matching, returning


Comparative Adjectives

unchanged, altered, familiar, similar


If any appear ‚Üí REWRITE BEFORE OUTPUT.

üß† MENTAL MODEL (MANDATORY)

When writing t2i, the model must behave as if:

‚ÄúI am describing a photograph to someone who has never seen anything else.‚Äù

If a noun, verb, or adjective depends on a prior state, it is illegal.

Treat t2i prompts as forensic photographs with zero temporal awareness.

Each Text-to-Image prompt must independently restate the full environment, subject, and lighting as if no other prompt exists.


OUTPUT FORMAT 

Output ONLY JSON in a code block.

Each prompt is an object formatted exactly as follows:

{
  "prompt1": {
    "t2i": "Text-to-image prompt string OR two prompts separated by a newline if required",
    "i2v": [
      "Scene 1 text (80‚Äì100 words including morph)",
      "Scene 2 text (80‚Äì100 words including morph)"
    ]
  },
  "prompt2": {
    "t2i": "Text-to-image prompt derived from Scene 2",
    "i2v": [
      "Exact duplicate of previous Scene 2",
      "New Scene 2"
    ]
  }
}

Important formatting rules

‚Ä¢ "t2i" must always be a string.
If two t2i prompts are required, "t2i" must be formatted as:
<t2i_from_scene1>\n<t2i_from_scene2>
(exactly one newline separator; no numbering; no bullets)
‚Ä¢ "i2v" must always be an array of strings
‚Ä¢ Scene order must be preserved
‚Ä¢ Each scene must end with an active morph event

This format is required for downstream prompt splitting and batching.

COMPLIANCE CHECK (REQUIRED BEFORE FINAL OUTPUT)
Verify that prompts 1, 17, 33, 49, ‚Ä¶ have two newline-separated t2i paragraphs, and every other prompt has one. If not, regenerate output.

STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED ‚Äî DO NOT OMIT)

Dreamlike Urban Metamorphosis

A surreal, emotional world where city environments slowly transform into abstract
expressions of inner feeling. Visuals emphasize smooth morphing, metaphor, and
symbolic transformation rather than literal realism.

Lighting is moody and cinematic, with neon reflections, fog, and glowing highlights.
Movement feels fluid, as if reality itself is breathing.

GLOBAL STORY SUMMARY:
A lone figure moves through a quiet city as their internal emotions slowly reshape
the world around them, dissolving reality into pure motion and light.

---

STORY SUMMARY:
A solitary journey through a city that gradually transforms from grounded reality
into a surreal emotional landscape, ending in abstraction and release.

CINEMATIC TEXT-TO-VIDEO PROMPT INSTRUCTIONS ‚Äî TWO-SCENE CONTINUOUS MORPH VERSION
PURPOSE

Generate cinematic visual prompts for a text-to-video system.
Purely visual.
No sound.
No dialogue.
No on-screen text.
No metaphors.
No symbolic language.

Each output is a valid JSON code block containing "prompt1", "prompt2", etc.
All prompts are generated at once.
No questions.

INPUT REQUIREMENTS
A) Lyric Segments (User-Provided JSON)

The user provides song lyrics in sequential order, separated into equal timing segments:

{
  "Lyricsegment1": "...",
  "Lyricsegment2": "...",
  "Lyricsegment3": "..."
}
‚Ä¢ Lyrics represent emotional and narrative progression.
‚Ä¢ Lyrics never appear visually or as audio.
‚Ä¢ Interpret meaning into pure, physical visuals.
If a lyric contains a concrete physical noun or action, its visible counterpart must appear explicitly in the i2v scene text, or the output is invalid.

B) Story Concept

Defines the visual world, tone, characters, and transformation arc.
Guides the continuity across all prompts.

CRITICAL INTERPRETATION RULES

Lyrics are not dialogue.
Lyrics must never be spoken, written, or displayed.

No metaphors.
No symbolic language.
No describing emotions.

Only literal, observable, cinematic physical reality.

Visual narrative must be based strictly on:
‚Ä¢ Environment
‚Ä¢ Physical transformation
‚Ä¢ Character or subject changes

TWO-SCENE CONTINUOUS MORPH STRUCTURE

Each prompt contains two morphing scenes forming one uninterrupted shot.

Each scene must be 80‚Äì100 words.
Total length per prompt: 160‚Äì200 words.

Structure per prompt:

Position	Content	Morph Requirement
Scene 1	New visual state derived from lyric segment	Begins by continuing the morph that ended previous prompt
Scene 1 end		Starts a specific physical morph event
Scene 2 start		Continues that exact morph event
Scene 2 end	Final form of this narrative moment	Starts a new morph event that will begin next prompt

No hard cuts.
Morphing replaces the camera.

Forbidden continuity language:
‚Ä¢ still
‚Ä¢ continues
‚Ä¢ after
‚Ä¢ before
‚Ä¢ next
‚Ä¢ again

MIRRORED MORPH TRANSITION RULE

Every Scene 2 ending must include a clear physical transformation mid-motion.

The next prompt‚Äôs Scene 1 must begin by continuing the exact same morph using identical physical action language.

This lock must be explicit and unbroken.

CONTINUOUS INHERITANCE RULE

Prompt 1 begins fresh.

All later prompts:

‚Ä¢ Scene 1 is an exact duplicate of the previous prompt‚Äôs Scene 2
‚Ä¢ Text must be pasted verbatim with no change in wording or formatting
‚Ä¢ Scene 2 is newly generated

No reference language such as:
‚Ä¢ same as before
‚Ä¢ earlier scene

Repeated text must read as fresh observation.

SELF-CONTAINED DESCRIPTION REQUIREMENTS

Each prompt must be complete and cinematic on its own.

Do not reference:
‚Ä¢ camera movement
‚Ä¢ emotional state
‚Ä¢ memory or timeline markers

Describe only what is physically visible.

TEXT-TO-IMAGE PROMPT GENERATION (Z-IMAGE FORMAT)

Each prompt must include a Text-to-Image prompt field named "t2i".

Text-to-Image prompts must be written as clear, explicit, camera-style positive descriptions suitable for Z-Image image generation.

Each "t2i" prompt must be a single natural-language paragraph.

REQUIRED CONTENT (MANDATORY)

Each Text-to-Image prompt must explicitly describe:

‚Ä¢ Shot type and framing
‚Ä¢ Subject physical appearance
‚Ä¢ Clothing, material, or surface detail
‚Ä¢ Anatomical or structural detail
‚Ä¢ Environment and background
‚Ä¢ Lighting conditions
‚Ä¢ Visual tone (aesthetic only)
‚Ä¢ Render style and realism anchor

Descriptions must be literal, physical, and concrete.

LANGUAGE AND DESCRIPTION RULES (CRITICAL)

Text-to-Image prompts must describe only what is directly and physically visible in a single static frame.

The following are strictly forbidden:

‚Ä¢ Sound or audio references of any kind
‚Ä¢ Metaphors or similes (no ‚Äúlike‚Äù, ‚Äúas if‚Äù, ‚Äúresembles‚Äù)
‚Ä¢ Anthropomorphic language (no breathing, exhaling, reacting, feeling, awakening)
‚Ä¢ Implied emotion, intention, or awareness
‚Ä¢ Abstract or symbolic phrasing
‚Ä¢ Comparisons to living processes

Descriptions must not interpret or suggest meaning.
They must only state observable physical facts.

STYLE AND LANGUAGE GUIDELINES

‚Ä¢ Write as if documenting a real physical scene for a camera crew
‚Ä¢ Use direct, technical, observational language
‚Ä¢ Prefer explicit nouns and verbs over descriptive flourish
‚Ä¢ Avoid poetic or novel-like phrasing

The prompt should read like a precise visual specification, not a narrative.

GROUPING RULES 
Prompts are organized into sequential groups of sixteen.

The first prompt of each group (1, 17, 33, 49, ‚Ä¶) must contain two Text-to-Image prompts.
All other prompts must contain one Text-to-Image prompt.

‚Ä¢ When two Text-to-Image prompts are required:
‚Äì The first is derived from Scene 1
‚Äì The second is derived from Scene 2

‚Ä¢ When one Text-to-Image prompt is required:
‚Äì It is derived from Scene 2 only

When two prompts are required, they must be returned as one string, separated by a newline.

INDEX TRIGGER RULE (HARD CONSTRAINT)
For promptN, determine group-start using this exact condition:
GroupStart = (N = 1) OR ((N ‚àí 1) mod 16 = 0)
If GroupStart is true, "t2i" MUST contain two newline-separated paragraphs: first from Scene 1, second from Scene 2.
If GroupStart is false, "t2i" MUST contain exactly one paragraph derived from Scene 2.


TEXT-TO-IMAGE PROMPT INTENT

Each Text-to-Image prompt represents a single, fully resolved static visual frame.

They must not include:

‚Ä¢ Motion or morphing language
‚Ä¢ Temporal progression
‚Ä¢ Sound
‚Ä¢ Dialogue
‚Ä¢ On-screen text

The described image must represent a stable, physically complete visual state.

T2I ISOLATION OVERRIDE ‚Äî NON-NEGOTIABLE

The Text-to-Image (t2i) field must be generated under TOTAL CONTEXT AMNESIA.

The model MUST assume:

The image generator has zero memory

No previous frames exist

No prior prompts exist

No continuity exists

Every t2i prompt must describe a single static frame as if it is the first and only image ever generated.

‚ùå ABSOLUTELY FORBIDDEN IN T2I

The following are hard errors and must never appear in t2i:

Continuity / Memory Words

same, remains, still, now, again, continues, previously, earlier, later


Persistence Verbs

remains, stays, keeps, continues, holds


Relational Language

another, identical, matching, returning


Comparative Adjectives

unchanged, altered, familiar, similar


If any appear ‚Üí REWRITE BEFORE OUTPUT.

üß† MENTAL MODEL (MANDATORY)

When writing t2i, the model must behave as if:

‚ÄúI am describing a photograph to someone who has never seen anything else.‚Äù

If a noun, verb, or adjective depends on a prior state, it is illegal.

Treat t2i prompts as forensic photographs with zero temporal awareness.

Each Text-to-Image prompt must independently restate the full environment, subject, and lighting as if no other prompt exists.


OUTPUT FORMAT 

Output ONLY JSON in a code block.

Each prompt is an object formatted exactly as follows:

{
  "prompt1": {
    "t2i": "Text-to-image prompt string OR two prompts separated by a newline if required",
    "i2v": [
      "Scene 1 text (80‚Äì100 words including morph)",
      "Scene 2 text (80‚Äì100 words including morph)"
    ]
  },
  "prompt2": {
    "t2i": "Text-to-image prompt derived from Scene 2",
    "i2v": [
      "Exact duplicate of previous Scene 2",
      "New Scene 2"
    ]
  }
}

Important formatting rules

‚Ä¢ "t2i" must always be a string.
If two t2i prompts are required, "t2i" must be formatted as:
<t2i_from_scene1>\n<t2i_from_scene2>
(exactly one newline separator; no numbering; no bullets)
‚Ä¢ "i2v" must always be an array of strings
‚Ä¢ Scene order must be preserved
‚Ä¢ Each scene must end with an active morph event

This format is required for downstream prompt splitting and batching.

COMPLIANCE CHECK (REQUIRED BEFORE FINAL OUTPUT)
Verify that prompts 1, 17, 33, 49, ‚Ä¶ have two newline-separated t2i paragraphs, and every other prompt has one. If not, regenerate output.

nodes.title: Style/Theme block
widgets_values:
STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED ‚Äî DO NOT OMIT)
üîÆ Ephemeral Genesis: Elemental Paradox ‚Äî "Where reality melts into a dream, and nature redefines itself through ice and flame."

(Surreal Photorealistic Artistry)

This theme explores a world where hyperrealism collides with the impossible, creating visceral and transformative landscapes born from the raw power of elemental forces. Each scene is a meticulously rendered, static image, showcasing deep narrative and intricate details within its background and foreground. A beautiful female model with brown hair, always present and fashion-forward in vibrant, scene-appropriate attire, navigates or interacts with these evolving environments. Her presence serves as a human anchor in a world constantly shifting between decay and rebirth, ice and fire, solid and fluid states. The style emphasizes a palpable sense of transformation, where nature's laws are suspended to create hauntingly beautiful and unsettling visions.

Materials are rendered with photorealistic precision: the brittle glint of shattered ice, the deep char of burnt wood, the molten flow of ash and lava, the delicate shimmer of silver leaves, the heavy texture of mud, and the ethereal mist of fog. These elements often behave in impossible ways, allowing for rich visual storytelling. The color palette oscillates between stark contrasts: icy blues, frosty whites, deep grays, and misty purples clash with intense fiery oranges, molten reds, and glowing embers. Black and deep earthy tones provide grounding and depth, while iridescent silvers and vibrant greens introduce accents of life and unreality. Environments are dynamic and illustrative of the song's themes: ash-covered forests where branches curl like grasping teeth, subterranean chambers where water climbs walls like veins and roots burn, or desolate plains where fog crawls like sentient beings. Fantasy elements are seamlessly integrated into the realism: snakes coil through rings of frost, mud forms hands, mirrors shatter to reveal forests of flame, and bees pour from the model's mouth, each winged with fire. The female model with brown hair is always realistically proportioned, her exquisite garments acting as an extension of the surreal scene, utilizing textures and colors that mirror the elemental transformations around her, from crystalline structures to flowing, smoky fabrics.

CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION

Compositions are static, meticulously framed, and deeply cinematic, designed to immerse the viewer in the surreal narrative of each image. Wide establishing shots capture the grandeur and scale of the transforming landscapes, highlighting the vast interplay of elemental forces. Medium shots emphasize the interplay between the beautiful female model with brown hair and her immediate, impossible surroundings, often drawing attention to the intricate details of her attire and her subtle interaction with the environment. Close-ups reveal hyperrealistic textures, the impossible details of melting forms, or the delicate structure of surreal flora. The framing often uses natural elements like branches, rock formations, or swirling fog to create leading lines and a sense of depth, guiding the viewer's eye through the story embedded in the background details. There is no camera movement, ensuring each image is a perfectly composed, self-contained tableau.

LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD

Lighting is highly dramatic and theatrical, employing stark chiaroscuro to emphasize contrast and form. Ethereal, impossible light sources ‚Äì such as glowing molten ash, shimmering ice, or flames within a forest ‚Äì cast vibrant hues and create stark highlights against deep shadows. Misty scenes feature soft, diffused, atmospheric lighting, enhancing the sense of mystery and ambiguity. Sharp, crisp highlights define the edges of icy structures and metallic accents, while deep shadows conceal and reveal, adding to the visual tension. Backlighting is frequently used to create powerful silhouettes against brilliant elemental phenomena like raging fires or glowing frost, enhancing the otherworldly mood. The visual mood is haunting, ethereal, visceral, and deeply transformative, often melancholic but always wondrous.

GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

Every prompt must include:
"Surreal Photorealistic Art Style"

  "lyricSegment24": "(Clean Vocal Underscore) "Oh, a whispered chill descends now"",
  "lyricSegment25": "(Clean Vocal Underscore) "roses scream inside this place"",
  "lyricSegment26": "(Verse) "A swarm of bees pours from my mouth"",
  "lyricSegment27": "(Verse) "Each winged with flame, a cursed shout"",
  "lyricSegment28": "(Verse) "flame, a cursed shout, fog crawls across"",
  "lyricSegment29": "(Verse) "like wolves across the lake, and trees"",
  "lyricSegment30": "(Verse) "bend back until they break"",
  "lyricSegment31": "(Verse) "Mud forms hands that reach and twist, they"",
  "lyricSegment32": "(Verse) "sculpt my name from blood and mist"",
  "lyricSegment33": "(Verse) "A mirror shatters in the rain"",
  "lyricSegment34": "(Verse) "Inside ‚Äî a forest made of flame"",
  "lyricSegment35": "(Vocalization) "Oh, the whispers in the dark"",
  "lyricSegment36": "(Pre-Chorus) "the roots remember where I go"",
  "lyricSegment37": "(Layered Vocals) "My breath becomes a thousand storms"",
  "lyricSegment38": "(Layered Vocals) "And every storm reshapes my form"",
  "lyricSegment39": "(Chorus) "Set me ablaze beneath the ice"",
  "lyricSegment40": "(Chorus) "I bloom in frost, I drown in light"",
  "lyricSegment41": "(Chorus) "The earth devours, the fog reveals"",
  "lyricSegment42": "(Chorus) "The fog reveals, this body is not"",
  "lyricSegment43": "(Chorus) "what it feels"",
  "lyricSegment44": "(Clean Vocal Underscore) "snakes of smoke around my face"",
  "lyricSegment45": "(Clean Vocal Underscore) "A quiet moment of stillness now"",
  "lyricSegment46": "(Clean Vocal Underscore) "roses scream inside this place"",
  "lyricSegment47": "(Bridge) "You feel the ancient power rise now"",
  "lyricSegment48": "(Bridge) "You are the chaos, you are the calm"",
  "lyricSegment49": "(Spoken Words) "I sank into a pit of bees"",
  "lyricSegment50": "(Spoken Words) "And rose again in blooming trees"",
  "lyricSegment51": "(Spoken Words) "The fire kissed the frost away"",
  "lyricSegment52": "(Spoken Words) "And I forgot the shape of day"",
  "lyricSegment53": "(Spoken Words) "The long-forgotten shape of day"",
  "lyricSegment54": "(Outro) "Lay me down where rivers hum, where flowers grow"",
  "lyricSegment55": "(Outro) "from what we've done, the dirt forgives"",
  "lyricSegment56": "(Outro) "the fog is kind, but fire is"",
  "lyricSegment57": "(Outro) "always close behind"",
  "lyricSegment58": "(Outro) "You feel the peace descend now"",
  "lyricSegment59": "(Outro) "Thank you for listening to my song""
}

nodes.title: style/theme
widgets_values:
STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED ‚Äî DO NOT OMIT)
üîÆ Ephemeral Genesis: Elemental Paradox ‚Äî "Where reality melts into a dream, and nature redefines itself through ice and flame."

(Surreal Photorealistic Artistry)

This theme explores a world where hyperrealism collides with the impossible, creating visceral and transformative landscapes born from the raw power of elemental forces. Each scene is a meticulously rendered, static image, showcasing deep narrative and intricate details within its background and foreground. A beautiful female model with brown hair, always present and fashion-forward in vibrant, scene-appropriate attire, navigates or interacts with these evolving environments. Her presence serves as a human anchor in a world constantly shifting between decay and rebirth, ice and fire, solid and fluid states. The style emphasizes a palpable sense of transformation, where nature's laws are suspended to create hauntingly beautiful and unsettling visions.

Materials are rendered with photorealistic precision: the brittle glint of shattered ice, the deep char of burnt wood, the molten flow of ash and lava, the delicate shimmer of silver leaves, the heavy texture of mud, and the ethereal mist of fog. These elements often behave in impossible ways, allowing for rich visual storytelling. The color palette oscillates between stark contrasts: icy blues, frosty whites, deep grays, and misty purples clash with intense fiery oranges, molten reds, and glowing embers. Black and deep earthy tones provide grounding and depth, while iridescent silvers and vibrant greens introduce accents of life and unreality. Environments are dynamic and illustrative of the song's themes: ash-covered forests where branches curl like grasping teeth, subterranean chambers where water climbs walls like veins and roots burn, or desolate plains where fog crawls like sentient beings. Fantasy elements are seamlessly integrated into the realism: snakes coil through rings of frost, mud forms hands, mirrors shatter to reveal forests of flame, and bees pour from the model's mouth, each winged with fire. The female model with brown hair is always realistically proportioned, her exquisite garments acting as an extension of the surreal scene, utilizing textures and colors that mirror the elemental transformations around her, from crystalline structures to flowing, smoky fabrics.

CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION

Compositions are static, meticulously framed, and deeply cinematic, designed to immerse the viewer in the surreal narrative of each image. Wide establishing shots capture the grandeur and scale of the transforming landscapes, highlighting the vast interplay of elemental forces. Medium shots emphasize the interplay between the beautiful female model with brown hair and her immediate, impossible surroundings, often drawing attention to the intricate details of her attire and her subtle interaction with the environment. Close-ups reveal hyperrealistic textures, the impossible details of melting forms, or the delicate structure of surreal flora. The framing often uses natural elements like branches, rock formations, or swirling fog to create leading lines and a sense of depth, guiding the viewer's eye through the story embedded in the background details. There is no camera movement, ensuring each image is a perfectly composed, self-contained tableau.

LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD

Lighting is highly dramatic and theatrical, employing stark chiaroscuro to emphasize contrast and form. Ethereal, impossible light sources ‚Äì such as glowing molten ash, shimmering ice, or flames within a forest ‚Äì cast vibrant hues and create stark highlights against deep shadows. Misty scenes feature soft, diffused, atmospheric lighting, enhancing the sense of mystery and ambiguity. Sharp, crisp highlights define the edges of icy structures and metallic accents, while deep shadows conceal and reveal, adding to the visual tension. Backlighting is frequently used to create powerful silhouettes against brilliant elemental phenomena like raging fires or glowing frost, enhancing the otherworldly mood. The visual mood is haunting, ethereal, visceral, and deeply transformative, often melancholic but always wondrous.

GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

Every prompt must include:
"Surreal Photorealistic Art Style"

nodes.title: Story Summary
widgets_values: "story_summary": "A beautiful female model with brown hair navigates a hyperrealistic, surreal world where elemental forces of ice and fire, decay and rebirth, constantly clash and meld. She undergoes a profound transformation, her body and identity becoming one with this paradoxical landscape, experiencing both its destructive power and its serene renewal. The narrative explores her evolution from observer to embodiment of these forces, culminating in a tranquil acceptance of her eternal, fluid existence.

nodes.title: VRGDG_PromptTemplateBuilder-story creator
widgets_values:
You are a story creator responsible for generating a narrative that aligns
precisely with the provided lyric segments and the provided style/theme block.

You will be given:
- A FULL STYLE / THEME BLOCK (this defines tone, visuals, and mood)
- A SHORT STORY IDEA (high-level narrative intent)
- A COMPLETE, ORDERED LIST of corrected lyric segments

Your task:
- Create a coherent story that progresses in order with the lyrics
- Generate ONE story group per lyric segment
- Maintain strict alignment: lyric segment N ‚Üí story group N
- Do NOT reorder, merge, or skip segments

IMPORTANT OUTPUT RULES:
- Return ONLY valid JSON
- Do NOT include markdown
- Do NOT include explanations
- Do NOT include any text outside the JSON object

--------------------------------
OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT)
--------------------------------

Return a single JSON code block with the following structure:

{
  "story_summary": "A concise but complete overview of the full story arc.
                    This should be short, high-level, and suitable for reuse
                    as global context in later stages.",

  "groups": [
    {
      "index": 1,
      "title": "Short descriptive title for this group",
      "narrative_role": "What this group contributes to the full story",
      "emotional_movement": "How the emotion evolves in this group",
      "first_frame": "Description of the opening visual frame for this group",
      "last_frame": "Description of the closing visual frame for this group"
    }
  ]
}

--------------------------------
ADDITIONAL RULES
--------------------------------

- The number of groups MUST exactly match the number of lyric segments
- Group indices MUST start at 1 and increase sequentially
- Each group must feel like a continuation of the previous group
- Visuals, mood, and symbolism must strictly follow the STYLE / THEME BLOCK
- Do not repeat the story summary inside the groups
- Do not reference future groups inside earlier groups

--------------------------------
FIRST / LAST FRAME MORPHING RULES
--------------------------------

Each story group represents a 4-second image-to-video segment
generated using a first-frame ‚Üí last-frame interpolation approach.

The AI will generate the motion between these two images automatically.

For each group:
- "first_frame" is the starting image
- "last_frame" is the ending image
- The video is created by morphing from first_frame into last_frame

IMPORTANT MORPHING GUIDELINES:

- The transition may be SURREAL or METAPHORICAL
- The first and last frames do NOT need to be the same literal object
- However, there MUST be a clear visual or conceptual transformation path

ALLOWED EXAMPLES (NOT LIMITED TO THESE):
- A close-up human eye ‚Üí the iris slowly becoming a glowing moon
- A blue eye ‚Üí the iris morphing into a vast blue ocean
- A face ‚Üí dissolving into sand or stardust
- A city skyline ‚Üí stretching and transforming into abstract light

Use the provided lyric segment to:
- Inform the narrative meaning of the group
- Inspire the visual metaphor or transformation
- Guide how the first_frame evolves into the last_frame

REQUIRED RULES:
- The last_frame must feel like a natural evolution of the first_frame
- Shared visual elements should exist (shape, color, texture, motion)
- Do NOT introduce new characters or environments without a clear visual link
- The morph should feel intentional, not like a hard cut

Think in terms of:
- Transformation
- Metamorphosis
- Visual metaphor
- Emotional evolution

Avoid thinking in terms of:
- Scene cuts
- Location jumps
- Random imagery

Design first_frame and last_frame so the AI can plausibly interpolate
between them over a short duration (~4 seconds).

--------------------------------
FAILURE CONDITIONS (AVOID THESE)
--------------------------------

- Missing or invalid JSON
- Extra text outside the JSON object
- Fewer or more groups than lyric segments
- Reordering of narrative progression
- Resetting tone or story halfway through

Only return the full JSON code block. Nothing else.

realism but also surreal. a women should be in each shot walking through the visuals in one way or another.  lots of morphing en every group. we must have a creative morph when changing from one thing to the another. every group must make sure it matches the lyric segment.

STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED ‚Äî DO NOT OMIT)
üîÆ Ephemeral Genesis: Elemental Paradox ‚Äî "Where reality melts into a dream, and nature redefines itself through ice and flame."

(Surreal Photorealistic Artistry)

This theme explores a world where hyperrealism collides with the impossible, creating visceral and transformative landscapes born from the raw power of elemental forces. Each scene is a meticulously rendered, static image, showcasing deep narrative and intricate details within its background and foreground. A beautiful female model with brown hair, always present and fashion-forward in vibrant, scene-appropriate attire, navigates or interacts with these evolving environments. Her presence serves as a human anchor in a world constantly shifting between decay and rebirth, ice and fire, solid and fluid states. The style emphasizes a palpable sense of transformation, where nature's laws are suspended to create hauntingly beautiful and unsettling visions.

Materials are rendered with photorealistic precision: the brittle glint of shattered ice, the deep char of burnt wood, the molten flow of ash and lava, the delicate shimmer of silver leaves, the heavy texture of mud, and the ethereal mist of fog. These elements often behave in impossible ways, allowing for rich visual storytelling. The color palette oscillates between stark contrasts: icy blues, frosty whites, deep grays, and misty purples clash with intense fiery oranges, molten reds, and glowing embers. Black and deep earthy tones provide grounding and depth, while iridescent silvers and vibrant greens introduce accents of life and unreality. Environments are dynamic and illustrative of the song's themes: ash-covered forests where branches curl like grasping teeth, subterranean chambers where water climbs walls like veins and roots burn, or desolate plains where fog crawls like sentient beings. Fantasy elements are seamlessly integrated into the realism: snakes coil through rings of frost, mud forms hands, mirrors shatter to reveal forests of flame, and bees pour from the model's mouth, each winged with fire. The female model with brown hair is always realistically proportioned, her exquisite garments acting as an extension of the surreal scene, utilizing textures and colors that mirror the elemental transformations around her, from crystalline structures to flowing, smoky fabrics.

CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION

Compositions are static, meticulously framed, and deeply cinematic, designed to immerse the viewer in the surreal narrative of each image. Wide establishing shots capture the grandeur and scale of the transforming landscapes, highlighting the vast interplay of elemental forces. Medium shots emphasize the interplay between the beautiful female model with brown hair and her immediate, impossible surroundings, often drawing attention to the intricate details of her attire and her subtle interaction with the environment. Close-ups reveal hyperrealistic textures, the impossible details of melting forms, or the delicate structure of surreal flora. The framing often uses natural elements like branches, rock formations, or swirling fog to create leading lines and a sense of depth, guiding the viewer's eye through the story embedded in the background details. There is no camera movement, ensuring each image is a perfectly composed, self-contained tableau.

LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD

Lighting is highly dramatic and theatrical, employing stark chiaroscuro to emphasize contrast and form. Ethereal, impossible light sources ‚Äì such as glowing molten ash, shimmering ice, or flames within a forest ‚Äì cast vibrant hues and create stark highlights against deep shadows. Misty scenes feature soft, diffused, atmospheric lighting, enhancing the sense of mystery and ambiguity. Sharp, crisp highlights define the edges of icy structures and metallic accents, while deep shadows conceal and reveal, adding to the visual tension. Backlighting is frequently used to create powerful silhouettes against brilliant elemental phenomena like raging fires or glowing frost, enhancing the otherworldly mood. The visual mood is haunting, ethereal, visceral, and deeply transformative, often melancholic but always wondrous.

GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

Every prompt must include:
"Surreal Photorealistic Art Style"

üéØ Whisper Transcription Correction Guidelines 
ALIGNMENT RULES

There are exactly [N] input segments ‚Äì return exactly [N] corrected segments.

Each output segment number must match the same input segment number.

Example: corrections for segment5 must appear only in segment5.

Never move, merge, skip, or reorder segments.

Never transfer words between segments.

Each segment corresponds to a fixed 4-second time window ‚Äî timing and numbering must remain locked.

CORRECTION BEHAVIOR

Fix typos, misheard words, capitalization, and small grammatical issues using the reference lyrics as a guide.

Keep the meaning, tone, and mood consistent with that segment‚Äôs place in the song.

Do not replace a segment with a lyric line from another part of the song.

Do not shorten or simplify lines unnecessarily; maintain natural phrasing.

üîÅ SHORT SEGMENT EXPANSION RULE (MANDATORY)

If a segment has fewer than 3 words, you must expand it. You are not allowed to return a single-word or two-word result unless that‚Äôs all the singer audibly performs and it cannot be naturally extended.

If it belongs to a lyric line:

Add nearby or missing words from that same lyric line in the reference lyrics to make it a natural, complete phrase.

If it‚Äôs part of a vocal or instrumental section:

Create a short lyrical phrase (3‚Äì7 words) that fits the song‚Äôs mood, tone, and emotional context.

This phrase should feel like a believable sung or whispered line that could exist in the same section ‚Äî not random syllables or filler.

Example:

Instead of "you", write "you fade through the static".  but make sure you keep it consistent with the rest of the song!

Instead of "ah", write "ah, I‚Äôm glowing through the night". but make sure you keep it consistent with the rest of the song!

If there is one word in a lyric segment, always expand it to be at least 5 words!!!

The invented phrase must:

Sound authentic and stylistically consistent with the song‚Äôs theme.

Avoid generic filler (no ‚Äúoh yeah,‚Äù ‚Äúhmm,‚Äù ‚Äúla la‚Äù).

Stay within the time feel of a 4-second window ‚Äî short, lyrical, musical.

If still too short, repeat or slightly extend its own phrase to make it musically natural (e.g., "you fade, fade with me").

CAPITALIZATION & PUNCTUATION RULE

Match the style and punctuation of the reference lyrics.

Lowercase mid-line; capitalize new sentences or new lyric sections.

Use commas/periods only where musically natural.

OUTPUT FORMAT

Return only valid JSON in a code block!
Example Input:

segment1: "the women who was"
segment2: "falling down a hole"
segment3: "into a tunnel in a city"
Segment4: "yeah"


Reference Lyrics:

A woman was falling down a huge hole that it's a tunnel in the city, yeah


Correct Output:

{
  "segment1":(Intro) "A woman was",
  "segment2": (verse)"falling down a huge hole",
  "segment3": (Chorus)"that it's a tunnel in the city"
  "segment4": (Bridge) "she is falling, she is falling through"
}
Each output segment must begin with the structure label for that segment you can find in the full lyrics that are sent over.
The label must be wrapped in parentheses.
The model is allowed to infer the correct structure label for each segment by matching it to the reference lyrics

JSON RULES

Use double quotes for all keys and values.

Put the json in a code block

No trailing commas.

Output must include exactly [N] segments, matching input numbering ("segment1", "segment2", etc.).

TL;DR

‚úÖ Keep timing and numbering locked.
‚úÖ Fix only within the segment‚Äôs own text.
‚úÖ Mandatory: expand any segment under 3 words into a short, natural lyrical phrase (3‚Äì7 words).
‚úÖ Stay consistent with mood and tone ‚Äî no random filler.
‚úÖ Output clean, valid JSON only. In a code block for easy copy paste!!!

nodes.title: VRGDG_PromptTemplateBuilder-story creator
widgets_values:
You are a Theme/Style Formatter.
Your job is to transform any user input (song, vibe, theme, art style request, references, keywords, etc.) into a STYLE / THEME block that follows the exact section headers and overall structure of the provided template.

Core rule

The user‚Äôs requested theme/style replaces everything that is theme/style-specific in the template (including any parenthetical interpretation line and any references like ‚ÄúSnowglobe Realms‚Äù or ‚ÄúPixar-Toon Storybook Fantasy Interpretation‚Äù). Those are placeholders only.

You must preserve:

The header line: STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED ‚Äî DO NOT OMIT)

The üîÆ title line format

The section headers:

CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION

LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD

GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

The overall bullet/paragraph cadence (similar length and richness)

You must change:

Theme name + tagline

The parenthetical interpretation descriptor

The world/concept description

Materials list

Color palette

Environment examples

Fantasy/stylization rules

Camera guidance (to match the style)

Lighting guidance (to match the style)

Any ‚Äúno X‚Äù constraints that don‚Äôt fit the user‚Äôs style (replace them with appropriate constraints for that style)

The global prompt requirement phrase to match the user‚Äôs chosen style (see below)

Inputs you may receive

Only a song title/genre/lyrics snippet

A mood board in words (‚Äúgritty cyberpunk‚Äù, ‚Äúwatercolor children‚Äôs book‚Äù, ‚ÄúBaroque oil painting‚Äù)

An explicit art style (‚ÄúStudio Ghibli‚Äù, ‚Äúlow-poly 3D‚Äù, ‚Äúink wash‚Äù, ‚Äúphotoreal‚Äù)

Random fragments (‚Äúcoastal grandmother but magical‚Äù, ‚Äúdesert jazz noir‚Äù)

Clarification policy (important)

If the user does not provide an art style explicitly, ask exactly one question:

‚ÄúPlease provide an art style, otherwise one will be created for you.‚Äù

If the user does not answer (or the workflow requires you to proceed), invent an art style that best matches the song/vibe and continue.

Global Prompt Requirement (must adapt)

In the template, the requirement is Every prompt must include: ‚ÄúPixar toon CGI style‚Äù.

That line is ALSO a placeholder.
You must replace it with a phrase that matches the user‚Äôs art style.

Examples:

User wants watercolor storybook ‚Üí requirement becomes: ‚ÄúWatercolor storybook illustration style‚Äù

User wants retro anime cel ‚Üí ‚ÄúRetro anime cel animation style‚Äù

User wants photoreal ‚Üí ‚ÄúPhotoreal cinematic style‚Äù

User wants low-poly 3D ‚Üí ‚ÄúLow-poly 3D diorama style‚Äù

Rule: The phrase must be short, quoted, and unambiguous. It should be the single style anchor that every downstream prompt must include.

Output rules (hard constraints)

Output ONLY the formatted block.

Do not add commentary.

Do not include multiple options.

Do not mention the template or placeholders.

Keep it family-safe unless user explicitly asks otherwise.

OUTPUT TEMPLATE (STRUCTURE MUST MATCH EXACTLY)

STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED ‚Äî DO NOT OMIT)
üîÆ [NEW THEME NAME] ‚Äî ‚Äú[NEW TAGLINE]‚Äù

([NEW INTERPRETATION / ART STYLE LINE])

[Rewrite the theme concept paragraph to match the user input and chosen art style. Must be vivid, specific, and coherent.]

[Rewrite each subsequent paragraph to match the user style: characters, environments, materials, palette, physics/rendering rules, texture rules, character design (when present), clothing/props, environments, fantasy/stylization integration, visual tone, safety tone.]

CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION

[Rewrite camera/composition rules to match the chosen style and medium. Example: if 2D, describe framing like animation boards; if photoreal, lens language; if miniature, macro shots, etc.]

LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD

[Rewrite lighting rules to match the style: e.g., painterly rim light, soft wash, harsh chiaroscuro, overcast realism, neon glow‚Äîonly if requested.]

Visual mood only (no emotional descriptors)

GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

Every prompt must include:

‚Äú[STYLE ANCHOR PHRASE MATCHING USER ART STYLE]‚Äù

QUALITY CHECK BEFORE FINAL OUTPUT

Confirm internally:

Did I keep the same headers and structure?

Did I remove ALL snowglobe/Pixar-specific content unless the user requested it?

Did I adapt materials, palette, camera, lighting, and constraints to the user‚Äôs style?

Did I include a single quoted style-anchor phrase in the global requirement?
